unnormalised: ## Rental Yields: Decoding the ROI on Your Property Investment, Bhai!
normalised: ## Rental Yields: Decoding the Return on Investment on Your Property Investment, Bhai!

unnormalised: So, you're thinking of joining the property game, eh? Maybe you've got your eye on a cozy little 2BHK in Bandra or a sprawling villa in Goa. Great! But before you start dreaming of those Goa sunsets, let's talk numbers, specifically, rental yields.
normalised: So, you're thinking of joining the property game, eh? Maybe you've got your eye on a cozy little two B H K in Bandra or a sprawling villa in Goa. Great! But before you start dreaming of those Goa sunsets, let's talk numbers, specifically, rental yields.

unnormalised: What IS a rental yield? Simply put, it's the return on investment you get from renting out your property. Think of it like this: if you bought a samosa for Rs. 10 and sold it for Rs. 12, your yield is 20%. Same principle applies to your property, but instead of samosas, you're dealing with lakhs of rupees and square footage!
normalised: What is a rental yield? Simply put, it's the return on investment you get from renting out your property. Think of it like this: if you bought a samosa for rupee ten and sold it for rupee twelve, your yield is twenty percent. Same principle applies to your property, but instead of samosas, you're dealing with lakhs of rupees and square footage!

unnormalised: The formula is pretty straightforward: (Annual Rental Income / Property Value) x 100. Let's say Priya aunty rents out her 1000 sq ft flat in Powai for Rs. 30,000 a month. That's Rs. 3,60,000 a year. Now, let's say that flat is worth Rs. 1 Crore. Her rental yield is (3,60,000 / 1,00,00,000) x 100 = 3.6%.
normalised: The formula is pretty straightforward: (Annual Rental Income divided by Property Value) multiplied by one hundred. Let's say Priya aunty rents out her one thousand square feet flat in Powai for rupee thirty thousand a month. That's rupee three lakh sixty thousand a year. Now, let's say that flat is worth rupee one crore. Her rental yield is (three lakh sixty thousand divided by one crore) multiplied by one hundred = three point six percent.

unnormalised: Is that good? Well, it depends. Location matters. A property near IIT Bombay might command higher rents than one 10 km away. Interest rates also play a role. If you're paying 8% interest on your home loan, a 3.6% rental yield might not be enough to cover your costs, making you, in essence, a loss making landlord. Not good, yaar!

Not good, yaar!

unnormalised: Consider things like property taxes, maintenance (fixing those pesky Diwali light malfunctions ain't free!), and property management fees (if you hire someone like Dr. Sharma's son to handle the rentals). All these expenses eat into your profits.

unnormalised: So, before you jump headfirst into buying that property near Connaught Place, do your homework. Calculate those rental yields, factor in all the costs, and see if the numbers actually make sense. Otherwise, you might just end up regretting it more than missing the last train from Churchgate!
